title: Find a job

parts.body:
Jobcentre Plus has one of Britain’s largest databases of job vacancies, which is updated constantly. You can [search for a job online](http://jobseekers.direct.gov.uk "search for a job online"){:rel="external"} - thousands of new jobs are available every week. 

You can also [look for voluntary work online](http://jobseekers.direct.gov.uk/homepagevw.aspx "look for voluntary work online"){:rel="external"}. Volunteering can help you develop and learn new skills while you’re looking for a job.
parts.title: Introduction

parts.body:
It’s useful to have a plan to help you manage the process of finding a job. 

The plan could include: 

##Looking for jobs every day##

Keep looking for jobs every day and think about what you can do to improve your search. This includes being flexible about the jobs you look for especially if you’re looking at a career change.

##Finding where to look for jobs##

Find out about where you could look for jobs locally, this could include:

- checking your local newspaper
- registering with a recruitment or employment agency
- asking friends and other people you know

##Updating your Curriculum Vitae (CV)##

You’ll need to keep your CV updated with your skills and strengths. These can include any professional skills and other strengths, eg good communication and flexibility 

You may also need to tailor your CV for different employers and sectors. Think about how often you will do that and make reviewing your CV a regular task.

The Jobcentre Plus ‘writing a CV’ factsheet has information and advice about writing your CV.

$D[Download 'writing a CV' factsheet PDF, 260KB](http://www.dwp.gov.uk/docs/jobkit-cv-writing.pdf "Download 'writing a CV' factsheet"){:rel="external"}$D
parts.title: Planning your job search

parts.body:
A good way to start is to make a list of your skills, strengths and previous experience and think about other jobs that might be a good match for you.

Strengths can include anything else that you can use to get a new job, eg good communication skills or flexibility.

If you think back to past jobs, hobbies and other activities, you probably already have some useful transferable skills, eg:

- good teamwork and communication skills from working in an office as part of a team 
- initiative and leadership skills from helping to run a Brownie or Cub pack in your spare time

It can sometimes be hard to recognise your own strengths - an interview with a Jobcentre Plus adviser can help. An adviser will know about other organisations that could help you identify and gain the skills you need. 

To speak to a Jobcentre Plus adviser, contact your local [Jobcentre Plus office](http://los.direct.gov.uk/default.aspx?type=1&lang=en "Jobcentre Plus office"){:rel="external"}.

##Developing new transferable skills##

You can develop new skills and experiences in lots of ways. You may want to:

- do some voluntary work 
- take part in a hobby, committee or group 
- do some part-time work 
- register with a recruitment or employment agency and do some temporary work 
- go on a training course
parts.title: Identifying your skills and strengths

parts.body:
When applying for a job you are competing against a lot of other people. It is important that your application makes an impression and stands out from the others.

When reading your application, the employer will be looking for information showing them that you can do the job. They will use this information to decide whether to invite you to an interview.

To increase your chances of getting invited to an interview make sure your:

- application concentrates on your skills and achievements that are important for the job
- information is relevant, clear and accurate for the job you’re applying for

The Jobcentre Plus ‘letters and application forms' factsheet contains information and advice about applying for jobs.

$D[Download ‘letters and application forms' factsheet PDF, 260KB](http://www.dwp.gov.uk/docs/jobkit-letters.pdf "Download ‘letters and application form' factsheet"){:rel="external"}$D
parts.title: Applying for jobs

parts.body:
Getting invited to an interview means you’ve passed the first test, your application must have made a good impression.

In the interview the employer tries to find out more about you. They will want to know if you can do the job and fit with the organisation and team. This is also your chance to talk about your skills and convince the employer that you are a good candidate.

Not everyone finds interviews easy, taking time planning for it will help, you could do this by:
	
- thinking about your skills and strengths and how they fit the job 
- finding out more about the organisation by researching the employer
- planning your journey to the interview 
- thinking about questions the employer might ask you and how you’ll answer them

The Jobcentre Plus 'preparing for an interview' factsheet contains information and advice about interviews.

$D[Download 'preparing for an interview' factsheet PDF, 260KB](http://www.dwp.gov.uk/docs/jobkit-interview-prep.pdf "Download 'preparing for an interview' factsheet"){:rel="external"}$D
